progress: IT'S THE FIRST DAY FO BOOTCAMP!! 🤩 During an enjoyable ice breaker activity, my three fellow bootcampers and I collaborated on the creation of a poem, signalling the start of our adventurous coding journey. At the School of Code, we learned the significance of teamwork through pair programming, experienced the CSS Diner challenge as a group, explored problem-solving techniques, and embraced computational thinking. One session's quote, "The only constant in the world is change," resonated deeply, highlighting the dynamic nature of the tech industry and the excitement of learning for future roles that may not even exist yet.
thoughts: I was a bit anxious starting SoC and juggling life alongside. However, I was set at ease straight away and really enjoyed meeting other bootcampers throughout the day. I started having a think about what I could work on for 100 days of code and will start next week. I enjoyed the fact that we were starting to learn how to learn and solve problems in a different way. I met my partner for the week, Sam who was very nice and has a background in computer science (and working in a toy shop!) which is very handy, so I can definitely learn a lot from him! Looking forward to this new adventure!!

progress: Throughout the bootcamp, we will be tackling various aspects of programming and problem-solving. We began by learning how to approach complex challenges, breaking them down using flow charts and Jamboard. One particularly tricky task was planning the SoC graduation ceremony, which required careful consideration. We delved deeper into computational thinking, exploring concepts such as decomposition, abstraction, pattern recognition, and algorithms. Refactoring became a valuable skill as we focused on reworking and organising code for improved maintainability and comprehension. We put our problem-solving abilities to the test with the Space Packer challenge, collaborating with a partner to write step-by-step algorithms. We were thrilled when we successfully solved the challenge. Another engaging activity involved revisiting Scratch, a programming language we hadn't used since applying to the bootcamp. However, the moment of truth arrived when we ventured into Git, navigating the terminal within VS Code and creating a new folder with a readme file to kick off our 100 days of code. We even established a new repository and pushed our progress to GitHub.
thoughts: I enjoyed the challenges today and revisiting problem solving again in a number of different ways, from breaking down a big challenge to working though a more defined game. Ending the afternoon with Git was a bit intense but Liz explained it very well and I think with practise I could get a better grasp of using Git through VS Code terminal as I have only used GitHub desktop before. You definitely feel like a bit of a coder when using the terminal!

progress: During the early part of the day, we were introduced to the concept of thinking like a computer, highlighting their literal nature. Communication with computers occurs through programming languages, such as the flexible JavaScript. We learned about REPL (Read, Evaluate, Print, Loop) and began exploring various coding concepts. Topics covered included variables, if/else statements, operators, and loops (such as while and for). Additionally, we delved into functions, discovering the existence of built-in JavaScript functions like alert and prompt. Parameters and arguments were explained as defining slots and providing input to functions, respectively. It was emphasised that the "=" symbol is an assignment operator, not an equals sign. Furthermore, we discussed the specifics of using while loops with the "i++" notation, denoting an increase by one. A fellow bootcamper shared a link to VS Code pets, and now I have a delightful little cat strolling across my screen, adding some extra enjoyment to the day. Lastly, we began utilising the Terminal for cloning, adding, committing, pushing, and pulling, as we embarked on our first workshop alongside my partner, Sam.
thoughts: It was good to get started on learning coding concepts and playing around in the console. I have done a little bit of coding before so the terminology was familiar. In isolation I think I have an ok understanding of variables, loops and functions but I think putting them together in practise to create something or solve a challenge will definitely be a challenge and something I will need to work on.

progress: The day began with a thought-provoking mindset workshop focused on giving and receiving feedback, emphasising the importance of perspectives. We explored different casing conventions used in programming languages and their significance. The usage of variables and different declaration keywords, such as let, const, and var, was discussed, highlighting their scoping behaviours. String interpolation using backticks for injecting variables within multiple lines of text was introduced. Loops, including for and while loops, were covered, emphasising the importance of avoiding infinite loops. We learned to create and manipulate arrays, as well as work with objects and access their key values. Selecting values from objects using dot notation or square brackets was explained. Additionally, we practiced looping over arrays and performed tasks like creating balance statements for customers. Git practice, including cloning repositories and collaborating with Sam on workshops, continued. I had an insightful meeting with my mentor, George Colingridge, where we discussed his role in the text team for RAC and his previous bootcamp experience. We talked about documenting my SoC journey, leveraging platforms like LinkedIn, and the idea of starting a project after a few weeks in the course. I look forward to our weekly meetings and his support throughout the course.
thoughts: We had quite a busy day of coding and learning new concepts. I think I need to practise a bit more with arrays and objects and pulling out certain types of information from them in the correct way and working it through logically. I understand for loops to a certain extent but would like to try using them more in practise, as well as in conjunction with arrays as I think they do confuse me somewhat. Starting to get the hang of Git and how you work together on a project with another person. Sam and I are getting on quite well with cloning repos from SoC GitHub classroom and taking it in turns to share our screens, working on a task together, then pushing our work so the other person can take over and pull/share their screen etc. Although I definitely still have to be reminded of the git commands for the terminal at times! Today we also came across an instance where I tried to pull the code that Sam had just pushed, but because I had unintentionally made a change on my local copy, there was a conflict and some scary error messages in the terminal! Something about stashing and then merging changes which we don’t understand yet but sure we will cover that later in the course! We somehow made it work (although I not sure how!).

progress: My first HACKATHON! We delved into the challenge of creating a Rock Paper Scissors game with our partners. After a week's recap, we brainstormed ideas on Jamboard and followed task lists to guide our progress. We discovered useful string functions like .charAt() and .slice(), as well as .toUpperCase(). Employing Math.floor() and Math.random() enabled the computer to make random selections. We emphasised adding comments for future reference, as revisiting code can be confusing during the learning process. While attempting user input validation, we encountered unfamiliar syntax that we plan to explore further. Through Git practice and pair programming with Sam, we gained confidence in collaborating and utilising GitHub.
thoughts: It was a really interesting challenge to work through - so much harder than it sounds! I learnt that is very important to set out a plan/the steps you are going to take before touching code, otherwise you can get very lost in it. I do look back on the code we put together and get a bit bogged down in the detail/how we actually created it but it’s so great we completed the game and it worked!! It will be great for reference going forward.

progress: I met my new partners, Gregor and Isaac, who were helpful in understanding the 'Penny Doubler' workshop. We had a quiz on data types, and I found a diagram useful for distinguishing between primitive and non-primitive types. We learned about accessing and manipulating the DOM using JavaScript, including using document.querySelector, .textContent, .style, document.createElement, .appendChild, and .removeChild. Gregor introduced the .splice() method, which I found interesting. Additionally, I learned about the ternary operator as an alternative to if/else statements.
thoughts: I had a terrible night as my daughter woke up at 4:30am this morning and my baby boy Otto has a tummy bug so bit crazy in our house at the moment but managed to get through the day and some interactive workshops definitely kept me on my toes!It was great meeting my new partners for the week and interested to work in a group of 3 as opposed to a pair. I think it’s great that we will get experience working with different people throughout the bootcamp. I like the fact that we could start manipulating webpages to make them more dynamic and see your code in action! There is so much that JavaScript can do in this respect which is exciting but all a bit daunting - lots to learn!

imageUrls.title: Data Types
imageUrls.alt: Diagram of primitive and non-primitive data types

progress: Not the easiest start to the day! My 3 year old daughter, Ada, was being a little madam, my little boy, Otto, who is nearly 1 is quite poorly and I ended up on the phone for ages trying to get through to 111 as I had some ailments too. So I had one of those days where I really felt like I had done a day’s work before even sitting down at my laptop at 9am! But I made it! 💪🏻 We tackled Codewars katas and learned about JavaScript array filter, opposite number function, and sentence smashing using the join function. We also explored making web pages more dynamic with event listeners and handling input events. The majority of the day was spent utilising AI tools like ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to create a rock paper scissors game. BREAK IT DOWN! This was the final message of the day and a very important one. I am still getting used to breaking the problem down and not getting overwhelmed by the challenge in front of me. This is also important when using the AI tools as the clearer you can be, the better they will be able to assist you!
thoughts: Today was a challenging day, both personally and ‘professionally’ as I had a lot going on (but don’t we all!). However I really enjoyed learning more about using the AI tools and learning how best to utilise them. I definitely found myself getting sidetracked and confused during the workshop/creation of the Rock, Paper, Scissors game. However, being reminded to break the challenge down into plain English and write a comment for each line of code really helps to keep you focused and take one step at a time. I thought it was quite funny how I used ChatGPT to generate the initial code blocks and found GitHub co-pilot wanting to help me write comments for it explaining how it works once I had copied it into VS Code. Finally, I have had a bit of wobble today feeling that I am quite behind. I have been super lucky to have worked with partners who are more advanced than me and have therefore learnt a lot but at the same time makes me feel like I need to learn so much more! But then I am reminded to only compare Day 7 Sarah to day 6 Sarah and no one else; I have definitely improved 😊

progress: In our group, we worked on Codewars katas and encountered a problem involving the .sort() method. This method sorts an array in place and returns the sorted array. We learned that when dealing with an array of numbers, you need to use a specific syntax for proper sorting, while for letters, the default sort order is ascending. We then moved on to learning about asynchronous JavaScript, which allows programs to perform long-running tasks while remaining responsive to other events. We discussed the analogy of following a recipe asynchronously, where you can start preparing other ingredients while one task is in progress. We also learned about the setTimeout() function, which executes code after a specified time, and the setInterval() function, which runs code at regular intervals. Both functions can use callback functions. Later, we focused on APIs and how to work with them. We discovered the fetch() method, which sends a request to an API and returns a promise. We used the await keyword to wait for the response and used the .json() method to unpack the JSON data. Finally, we emphasised the importance of always awaiting a promise, and we learned that promises can be resolved, pending, or rejected.
thoughts: Today was a very busy day with A LOT of new information to take in. I can see how powerful it is using APIs and apparently we will be creating our own APIs at some point which seems crazy at the moment! I definitely need more practise with this but hoping I have made a good start in trying to understand the concepts. The workshop at the end of day which required us to create a page that pulled information from an API and display this information in various ways was a real challenge! I was definitely very confused at times but it was great working with Gregor and Isaac who talked it through with me (not forgetting our favourite AI tools lending a hand too!). You really do need to break down a challenge like that, otherwise you get completely lost! I did the personality quiz reading for the mindset session tomorrow and apparently I am a Protagonist! I enjoyed the energiser today and decided that the image below best represents asynchronicity in my life (lots going on behind the scenes i.e. life with a young family, alongside me working hard on the bootcamp!) 😂

imageUrls.title: Asynchronicity: Daily Energiser Exercise ✍️
imageUrls.alt: Image of a calm coder on the surface but a lot going on behind the scenes

progress: Today's coding session started with Codewars challenges, where we came across a tricky one that required extracting the middle character(s) from a word. We used `Math.floor()` and `Math.ceil()` methods to handle odd and even word lengths, returning either the single middle character or the two middle characters accordingly. An alternative approach using `s.substr()` was also explored, simplifying the code further. The UX/UI talk with Paavan Buddhdev was captivating as he delved into the world of user experience and interface design. Titled "Do UX Believe in Magic?," the session highlighted the role of storytelling in design, leveraging narrative structures to create compelling experiences. Paavan emphasised predictability, citing Jakob's Law, which suggests that users prefer digital products to work similarly to what they are accustomed to. We explored attention manipulation and Hick's Law, where decision-making time increases with more choices, emphasising the importance of intuitive design. The talk also touched on avoiding blind spots in design and injecting moments of wonder to delight users unexpectedly. Examples included animated elements for positive actions and small surprises like Gousto's wooden spoon or Monzo's personalised thank-you messages. Such magical experiences enhance user satisfaction and foster loyalty. In the afternoon, we participated in a research task, working in groups to create a 5-minute video presentation. Our topic was "Dev tools we haven't used yet," and we discussed various handy tools. My favourite was the Toggle Device toolbar, which allows testing website responsiveness across different devices and network connections, providing valuable insights for optimising user experiences. The day was filled with exciting learning opportunities, ranging from coding challenges to understanding human behaviour in the context of design and teamwork dynamics.
thoughts: I really enjoyed the mindset session today. We took the Myers-Briggs test, and I discovered my personality type as ENFJ-T, also known as the Protagonist. We discussed how different personalities can collaborate effectively in a team, recognising the potential for conflicts and the importance of resolving them by appreciating others' perspectives and working styles. The key takeaway was that diverse teams can be highly valuable if everyone respects and understands one another. I think I will definitely develop my soft skills during the bootcamp and look forward to working in different teams going forward.

imageUrls.title: Enjoying my new Crocs to get to and from the garden office/studio 👟
imageUrls.alt: Image of a pair of crocs with decorative jibbitz

progress: HACKATHON day! We decided to create a Pokemon game using the PokeAPI, which initially seemed daunting due to the abundance of Pokemon stats in the API. We focused on comparing Pokemon in a 'Poke Battle' using stats and health points. The team utilised the concept of "truthy" values, checking if data from the API was available before running the battle function. We learned the importance of proper code organisation, ensuring functions and variables were defined before being used, and collaborated closely to troubleshoot and comment on the code. We did get some useful tips from ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot which were extremely helpful when we got stuck. This exercise also helped us to recognise the significance of writing code in a readable, understandable way, avoiding excessively condensed AI-generated code. We enjoyed designing the Pokemon game page and experimenting with styling, gaining further experience in CSS despite the occasional frustrations! Again the importance of teamwork was evident (I would be lost by myself!)
thoughts: I really enjoyed the task today and learnt a bit more about Pokemon from Gregor and Isaac who are big fans! We worked at quite a fast pace as my partners for the week are more advanced than me but I learnt a lot! I think the only downside to this is that I probably still don’t quite completely understand the code we have written and how it all fits together but I am going to go through it again and make sure I am more comfortable with it. The game looks great and love the old school feel to the styling 😊 Ready for the weekend and Otto’s 1st birthday party 🥳
